0.93.text:
Alice: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English.
I'm Alice.

4.94.text:
Alice: Hello, Neil. You went to university,
didn't you?

8.20.text:
Neil: Yes. University – the best days of
my life.

11.64.text: I made fantastic friends, went to great parties...

16.06.text:
Neil: Well, yeah, I did some work, but probably
not enough.

19.99.text:
Alice: Well, the subject of today's show is
student mental health.

24.17.text: So, Neil, do you think you're looking back at your university days through rose-tinted spectacles?

29.99.text: And that means looking at a situation as being better than it really was.

33.75.text:
Neil: I did feel out of my comfort zone when
I arrived. Yes, everyone seemed to know everyone...

39.96.text:
Alice: Yes, well, being out of your comfort
zone means being in a situation that you aren't

44.78.text: familiar with and which makes you feel nervous.

48.14.text: Did you talk to anyone about your feelings, Neil?

53.04.text: And that means professional help with personal or psychological problems.

57.00.text:
Neil: What? No, not me. I'm one of those men
who isn't good at talking about their feelings, Alice.

63.86.text: I just felt a bit homesick that's all – I missed my friends and family.

68.76.text: But let's move on, shall we! Why don't you ask me today's quiz question?

72.37.text:
Alice: Alright then. So here it is: In a survey
of students at Imperial College London,

78.49.text:
how many students said they suffered from high
levels of stress

81.95.text: or a mental health condition during their time at college? Was it... a) 1 out of 4?

88.80.text:
b) 2 out of 4?
or c) 3 out of 4?

94.84.text: Neil: Well, I'm going to go for c) 3 out of 4

97.26.text: because I do think that university life can be more stressful than people realize.

101.65.text:
Alice: Yes. And stress means pressure or worry
caused by a difficult situation.

107.27.text: OK, we'll find out if you're right or wrong later on.

110.87.text: Now in the UK, there has been a rise in students using counselling services.

116.98.text:
Alice: Well, let's listen to Kirsty, a student
at Exeter University,

120.78.text: talking about why shehas had problems.

123.38.text: And here's a question for you while you listen: Did she enjoy her first days in college?

130.58.text:
Kirsty McMurron: No. The thing is... it...
is a real balancing act.

133.50.text: When I first got to university I don't think I'd really realized that

136.98.text: I'd forgotten how to make friends you know,

139.54.text:
I'd been with the same school friends
for seven years,

142.00.text: and so I was trying to balance... you know

148.62.text: whilst learning how to look after myself at quite a young age.

151.96.text: And I think that's the experience of a lot of young people. And people really struggle with it.

158.30.text: Neil: What's a balancing act, Alice?

159.99.text:
Alice: It's where you try to give your attention
to two or more things at the same time.

165.17.text:
So here, Kirsty is trying to balance making new
friends with doing her academic work

170.27.text: and learning to look after herself.

172.52.text:
Neil: What does Kirsty mean when she says
she's learning to look after herself?

176.80.text:
Alice: Well, to look after someone means to
protect or take care of someone

181.26.text:
and in this case, Kirsty's learning to take care
of herself

184.84.text: for example doing her own shopping and cooking.

187.76.text:
Neil: OK, let's listen to Dr Ruth Caleb of
the counselling service at Brunel University in London

193.80.text:
talking about what practical stuff
students could learn before leaving for university

199.14.text: that might make life easier for them.

203.08.text:
Dr Ruth Caleb: Certain things that I think
it would be very very helpful for students

207.56.text:
to have put in place are an ability to do
the practical things of life

211.52.text:
to do the washing, to do the cleaning and so on –
being able to cook.

216.96.text: Budgeting is extremely important in university life.

221.70.text: And also spending time on your own comfortably.

227.12.text:
Neil: Yes, that's excellent advice. I couldn't
boil an egg when I arrived at uni.

231.19.text: Alice: Oh, really? Can you do it now, Neil?

234.63.text:
Alice: Yeah? Great. And what about budgeting?
This means planning how much money you have

239.33.text: and how you will spend it.

240.82.text: Neil: I'm still pretty bad at that.

243.56.text: However, I am very good at spending time on my own comfortably.

246.98.text:
Alice: Yes, I can believe that – feet up,
watching TV with a takeaway.

250.64.text:
Neil: Takeaway, of course a takeaway cause
I can't cook anything...

253.68.text:
Neil: ... not even an egg. You know me so
well. So how about the answer to today's quiz

259.86.text:
Alice: Alright then. I asked: In a survey
of students at Imperial College London,

264.74.text: how many said they suffered from high levels of stress or a mental health condition during their time at college?

277.04.text:
b) 2 out of 4?
or c) 3 out of 4?

282.58.text: Neil: And I said c) 3 out of 4.

285.62.text:
Alice: Yes. And you are correct – well
done, Neil!

289.64.text: The survey, completed by over a thousand students,

292.56.text: also found that almost 70% of those that suffer from stress do so at least once a week,

298.52.text: and 9% of students feel stressed constantly. Stressed means anxious worry.

304.52.text:
Neil: Well, I feel anxious just thinking about
all that stress. Can we hear today's words again?

309.95.text: Alice: We certainly can. They are:

339.18.text:
Neil: Well, that brings us to the end of today's
6 Minute English.

343.14.text: We hope you've had a stress-free time.

345.76.text:
Please do join us again soon. You know
where to find us, don't you?

352.27.text:
where you'll find grammar points, vocabulary
and more editions of 6 Minute English.
